exercises.question: He said that he ___ hungry.
exercises.hint: In reported speech, 'am/is' usually changes to 'was'.
exercises.example_sentence: He said that he was hungry, so we went to a restaurant.

exercises.question: Which is the correct reported form of: 'I like pizza'?
exercises.hint: The Present Simple changes to Past Simple.
exercises.example_sentence: She said she liked pizza, but she didn't want any today.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: He told me he was late
exercises.hint: Use 'told' when there is an object like 'me'.
exercises.example_sentence: He told me he was late because of the traffic.

exercises.question: Match the Direct Speech to its Reported form (Shuffled).
exercises.hint: Check for pronoun and tense changes.
exercises.example_sentence: He said he was tired after the long flight.

exercises.question: Repeat: She said she was happy.
exercises.example_sentence: She said she was happy with the results.

exercises.question: They told us that they ___ at home.
exercises.example_sentence: They told us that they were at home all evening.

exercises.question: What is the difference between 'said' and 'told'?
options: We use 'told' with a person (told me), and 'said' without (said that).
'Said' is for the past, 'told' is for the future.
exercises.answer: We use 'told' with a person (told me), and 'said' without (said that).
exercises.example_sentence: I told him the truth, but he said that I was wrong.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: She said the bank was closed
exercises.example_sentence: She said the bank was closed when she arrived.

exercises.question: Match the verb shift
exercises.hint: Think about how the tense goes 'back' in time.
exercises.example_sentence: She said she could help me.

exercises.question: Repeat: He told me he lived in London.
exercises.answer: He told me he lived in London.
exercises.hint: The original was 'I live in London'.
exercises.example_sentence: He told me he lived in London for three years.

exercises.question: She said she ___ play the piano.
exercises.example_sentence: She said she could play the piano very well.

exercises.question: Report this: 'I am working.'
exercises.example_sentence: I called him, and he said he was working.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: She said she didn't have money
exercises.example_sentence: She said she didn't have money for the tickets.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun changes
exercises.hint: You must change the subject when reporting.
exercises.example_sentence: We said we were coming -> They said they were coming.

exercises.question: Repeat: They said they didn't know.
exercises.example_sentence: I asked them, but they said they didn't know the way.

exercises.question: I ___ him that I was busy.
exercises.example_sentence: I told him that I was busy and couldn't talk.

exercises.question: Report this: 'I'll call you.'
options: He said he would call me.
He said he will call me.
exercises.answer: He said he would call me.
exercises.example_sentence: He said he would call me later in the evening.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: He said he wanted to go home
exercises.example_sentence: He was tired, so he said he wanted to go home.

exercises.question: Match the direct verb to the reported verb
exercises.hint: Change the present verb to its past form.
exercises.example_sentence: She said she knew the answer.

exercises.question: Repeat: You told me you were ready.
exercises.answer: You told me you were ready.
exercises.hint: A gentle reminder of what someone said.
exercises.example_sentence: Come on! You told me you were ready five minutes ago.

exercises.question: This isn't my coat. Is it ___?
exercises.example_sentence: This isn't my coat. Is it yours?

exercises.question: Which sentence uses a possessive pronoun correctly?
exercises.hint: Pronouns stand alone without a noun.
exercises.example_sentence: That blue car is mine.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: That bag is not hers; it belongs to Sarah.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the pronoun.
exercises.hint: Adjectives need a noun; pronouns do not.
exercises.example_sentence: This is my house. The house is mine.

exercises.question: Repeat: The decision is ours.
exercises.hint: Focus on the 'z' sound at the end of 'ours'.
exercises.example_sentence: We discussed it together, so the decision is ours.

exercises.question: He found a pen. He thinks it is ___.
exercises.example_sentence: He found a pen on the floor and thinks it is his.

exercises.question: What is the pronoun for 'Their house'?
exercises.hint: Add an 's' to the adjective form.
exercises.example_sentence: Our house is small, but theirs is very large.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: There are two cups here. Which coffee is yours?

exercises.question: Match the person to the pronoun.
exercises.example_sentence: The bike is his, and the ball is hers.

exercises.question: Repeat: Are these keys yours?
exercises.hint: Rising intonation for a yes/no question.
exercises.example_sentence: I found these on the table. Are these keys yours?

exercises.question: I've finished my homework. Have you finished ___?
exercises.example_sentence: I've finished my homework. Have you finished yours?

exercises.question: Complete the sentence: 'It's not my fault, it's ___.'
exercises.example_sentence: It's not my fault the project is late; it's theirs.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: This phone is not mine; I have a different model.

exercises.question: Match the sentence halves.
exercises.example_sentence: I have my umbrella, so you can keep yours.

exercises.question: Repeat: Everything here is mine.
exercises.example_sentence: I bought all of this. Everything here is mine.

exercises.question: We bought this house together, so it is ___.
exercises.example_sentence: We bought this house together, so it is ours.

exercises.question: Is 'it's' a possessive pronoun?
options: No, it is a contraction of 'it is'.
Yes, it is the same as 'his'.
exercises.answer: No, it is a contraction of 'it is'.
exercises.example_sentence: It's a cat. Its tail is long.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: There are many dresses. The red one is hers.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to its usage.
exercises.example_sentence: Mine is over there.

exercises.question: Repeat: This book is mine, not yours.
exercises.answer: This book is mine, not yours.
exercises.example_sentence: Please give it back. This book is mine, not yours.

exercises.question: He ran very ___ to catch the bus.
exercises.example_sentence: He ran very quickly to catch the bus before it left.

exercises.question: What is the adverb for the word 'good'?
exercises.example_sentence: She speaks English very well.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: She carried the glass carefully so she wouldn't drop it.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the adverb.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a slow walker. He walks slowly.

exercises.question: Repeat: Please speak quietly in the library.
exercises.answer: Please speak quietly in the library.
exercises.example_sentence: The students are studying, so please speak quietly.

exercises.question: The children played ___ together.
exercises.example_sentence: The children played happily together in the garden.

exercises.question: Which word is an irregular adverb (no -ly)?
exercises.hint: The adjective and adverb are the same.
exercises.example_sentence: He drives a fast car and he drives fast.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: He studied hard for the test
exercises.example_sentence: He studied hard for the test to get a good grade.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the irregular adverb.
exercises.hint: These do not follow the -ly rule.
exercises.example_sentence: You did a good job; you worked well.

exercises.question: Repeat: Can you drive more slowly?
exercises.example_sentence: The road is dangerous. Can you drive more slowly?

exercises.question: She finished her work ___ and left the office.
exercises.example_sentence: She finished her work easily because she is very skilled.

exercises.question: Choose the correct adverb for 'bad':
exercises.example_sentence: The team played badly and lost the game.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The dog barked loudly at night
exercises.example_sentence: The dog barked loudly at night and woke up the neighbors.

exercises.question: Match the opposite adverbs.
exercises.example_sentence: He sings well, but he dances badly.

exercises.question: Repeat: Please listen carefully.
exercises.example_sentence: I have important news, so please listen carefully.

exercises.question: The cat moved ___ through the grass.
exercises.example_sentence: The cat moved silently through the grass to catch the bird.

exercises.question: Complete: 'It is raining ___.'
exercises.example_sentence: It is raining heavily, so don't forget your umbrella.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The teacher spoke clearly to the class
exercises.example_sentence: The teacher spoke clearly so everyone could understand.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the adverb spelling.
exercises.hint: Watch for spelling changes in words ending in -e or -y.
exercises.example_sentence: He spoke angrily after the mistake.

exercises.question: Repeat: He works hard every day.
exercises.hint: Remember 'hard' doesn't take -ly in this context.
exercises.example_sentence: He wants a promotion, so he works hard every day.

exercises.question: If it rains tomorrow, I ___ stay at home.
exercises.hint: Use 'will' for the result part of the first conditional.
exercises.example_sentence: If it rains tomorrow, I will stay at home and watch a movie.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a correct First Conditional?
options: If I see him, I tell him.
If I see him, I will tell him.
If I will see him, I will tell him.
exercises.answer: If I see him, I will tell him.
exercises.hint: The 'if' clause uses Present Simple, not 'will'.
exercises.example_sentence: If I see him at the office, I will tell him about the meeting.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If you are late you will miss the bus
exercises.example_sentence: If you are late, you will miss the start of the bus.

exercises.question: Match the condition to the result.
exercises.example_sentence: If you study hard, you will pass with a high grade.

exercises.question: Repeat: I'll help you if I have time.
exercises.answer: I'll help you if I have time.
exercises.hint: The result can come before the 'if' clause.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll help you with your homework if I have time tonight.

exercises.question: If she ___ early, she will catch the train.
exercises.hint: Use Present Simple in the 'if' part.
exercises.example_sentence: If she leaves early, she will catch the 8:00 AM train.

exercises.question: What is the negative form?
options: If you don't hurry, you'll be late.
If you won't hurry, you'll be late.
If you not hurry, you'll be late.
exercises.answer: If you don't hurry, you'll be late.
exercises.hint: Use 'don't' or 'doesn't' for the negative condition.
exercises.example_sentence: If you don't hurry, you'll be late for the concert.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If I have enough money I will buy a car
exercises.example_sentence: If I have enough money, I will buy a car next year.

exercises.question: Match the clauses.

pairs.right: we will go to the beach

answer.right: we will go to the beach

exercises.example_sentence: If it is sunny, we will go for a swim.

exercises.question: Repeat: If I'm free, I'll call you.
exercises.answer: If I'm free, I'll call you.
exercises.example_sentence: If I'm free after work, I'll call you immediately.

exercises.question: We ___ go to the park if the weather is good.
exercises.hint: The result is a future possibility.
exercises.example_sentence: We will go to the park if the weather is good this weekend.

exercises.question: Choose the correct verb: 'If he ___ me, I'll be happy.'
exercises.hint: He/She/It takes -s in the present simple.
exercises.example_sentence: If he calls me tonight, I'll be very happy.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If you don't go to sleep you will be tired
exercises.hint: Negative condition leads to a negative state.
exercises.example_sentence: If you don't go to sleep now, you will be tired tomorrow.

exercises.question: Match the sentence halves.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll be angry if you are late again.

exercises.question: Repeat: What will you do if it's closed?
exercises.answer: What will you do if it's closed?
exercises.example_sentence: What will you do if the store is closed when you get there?

exercises.question: If you don't eat now, you ___ be hungry later.
exercises.example_sentence: If you don't eat now, you will be hungry during the flight.

exercises.question: Complete: 'If they ___ hard, they will win.'
exercises.hint: 'They' uses the base form of the verb.
exercises.example_sentence: If they practice hard, they will win the game on Saturday.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: She will get wet if she doesn't use an umbrella
exercises.example_sentence: She will get wet if she doesn't use an umbrella in this rain.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to the verb form.
exercises.example_sentence: If he sees me, he will be surprised.

exercises.question: Repeat: Everything will be fine if you relax.
exercises.answer: Everything will be fine if you relax.
exercises.example_sentence: Don't worry about the presentation; everything will be fine if you relax.

exercises.question: If the weather is nice tomorrow, we ___ go for a walk.
exercises.example_sentence: If the weather is nice tomorrow, we will go for a walk in the park.

exercises.question: Which sentence is in the Past Continuous?
options: I was watching TV when you called.
I watched TV when you called.
exercises.answer: I was watching TV when you called.
exercises.example_sentence: I was watching TV when you called, so I didn't hear the phone at first.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: My brother is taller than me
exercises.example_sentence: My brother is taller than me, even though he is younger.

exercises.question: Match the pronoun to its type.
exercises.hint: Recall the grammar categories from Batches 32 and 34.
exercises.example_sentence: This book is mine, and I have something to tell you.

exercises.question: Repeat: She said she was tired.
exercises.example_sentence: I asked her to go out, but she said she was tired.

exercises.question: I only have ___ money left in my wallet.
exercises.example_sentence: I only have a little money left, so I can't buy lunch.

exercises.question: What does 'take off' mean when talking about a plane?
exercises.example_sentence: The plane will take off in ten minutes.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The movie that we saw was boring
exercises.example_sentence: The movie that we saw yesterday was very boring.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the adverb.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a good driver and drives carefully.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is there anyone in the room?
exercises.answer: Is there anyone in the room?
exercises.example_sentence: The lights are on. Is there anyone in the room?

exercises.question: I ___ to live in Madrid when I was a child.
exercises.example_sentence: I used to live in Madrid when I was a child, but now I live in London.

exercises.question: Choose the superlative form of 'expensive':
exercises.hint: Used for the top of a category.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the most expensive watch in the store.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I have not finished my homework yet
exercises.example_sentence: I have not finished my homework yet, so I can't play games.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the feeling.
exercises.example_sentence: The boring book made the student feel bored.

exercises.question: Repeat: Can you turn down the music?
exercises.answer: Can you turn down the music?
exercises.example_sentence: It's too loud in here. Can you turn down the music?

exercises.question: The man ___ stole the car was arrested.
exercises.example_sentence: The man who stole the car was arrested by the police.

exercises.question: Which is correct for a future plan?
options: I am going to visit my grandmother.
exercises.answer: I am going to visit my grandmother.
exercises.example_sentence: I am going to visit my grandmother next Sunday.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: She doesn't dance very well, but she enjoys it.

exercises.question: Match the time expression to the tense.
exercises.example_sentence: Last year I travelled to Japan; right now I am at home.

exercises.question: Repeat: They told me they were busy.
exercises.answer: They told me they were busy.
exercises.example_sentence: I asked them for help, but they told me they were busy.

exercises.question: While I ___ breakfast, the phone rang.
exercises.hint: Use Past Continuous for a long action interrupted by a short one.
exercises.example_sentence: While I was having breakfast, the phone rang suddenly.

exercises.question: Which sentence correctly uses a relative pronoun for a person?
options: The girl who sits next to me is kind.
The girl which sits next to me is kind.
The girl where sits next to me is kind.
exercises.answer: The girl who sits next to me is kind.
exercises.example_sentence: The girl who sits next to me in class is very kind.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Their house is smaller than ours
exercises.example_sentence: Their house is smaller than ours, but it is very modern.

exercises.question: Match the question to the correct response.
exercises.example_sentence: Whose bag is this? Oh, it's mine, thank you.

exercises.question: Repeat: He doesn't have much money.
exercises.hint: Focus on the quantifier for uncountable nouns.
exercises.example_sentence: He doesn't have much money, but he is very happy.

exercises.question: I have ___ friends who live in London.
exercises.example_sentence: I have a few friends who live in London, so I visit them often.

exercises.question: What is the reported version of: 'I am lost'?
options: He said he will be lost.
exercises.hint: Shift the present tense to the past.
exercises.example_sentence: He called me and said he was lost in the city center.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: She didn't say anything to me
exercises.example_sentence: She was very quiet and didn't say anything to me.

exercises.question: Match the adjective to the irregular adverb.
exercises.hint: These adverbs do not change form.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a fast runner and he runs fast.

exercises.question: Repeat: This is the car which I bought.
exercises.answer: This is the car which I bought.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the car which I bought from my neighbor.

exercises.question: If you study, you ___ pass.
exercises.example_sentence: If you study every day, you will pass the exam easily.

exercises.question: Which adverb describes 'doing something in a quiet way'?
exercises.example_sentence: Please walk quietly while the baby is sleeping.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is nobody in the office
exercises.example_sentence: The building is dark; there is nobody in the office.

exercises.question: Match the tense to the sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: I was eating when you called.

exercises.question: Repeat: Is that your pen or mine?
exercises.answer: Is that your pen or mine?
exercises.example_sentence: We have the same pen. Is that your pen or mine?

exercises.question: She is the woman ___ works in the library.
exercises.example_sentence: She is the woman who works in the library on Tuesdays.

exercises.question: Complete: 'I have ___ water left.'
exercises.example_sentence: I have a little water left, do you want some?

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: The team played well yesterday and won the game.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verb to its meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I need to look for my keys.

exercises.question: Repeat: If I see her, I'll tell her.
exercises.answer: If I see her, I'll tell her.
exercises.example_sentence: If I see her at the party, I'll tell her you said hello.

exercises.question: He is not ___ tall ___ his father.
exercises.hint: Use this structure to compare two equal (or unequal) things.
exercises.example_sentence: He is not as tall as his father yet, but he is growing fast.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses a future possibility?
exercises.hint: Use 'might' when you are not 100% sure.
exercises.example_sentence: Take an umbrella because it might rain later this afternoon.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: I enjoy swimming in the ocean
exercises.hint: The verb 'enjoy' is followed by the -ing form.
exercises.example_sentence: I enjoy swimming in the ocean during the summer holidays.

exercises.question: Match the verb to the correct pattern.
exercises.example_sentence: I want to go home after I finish reading this book.

exercises.question: Repeat: The cat ran across the road.
exercises.answer: The cat ran across the road.
exercises.hint: Preposition of movement: from one side to the other.
exercises.example_sentence: The cat ran across the road very quickly.

exercises.question: You ___ smoke in the hospital. It is forbidden.
exercises.example_sentence: You mustn't smoke in the hospital because it is a smoke-free zone.

exercises.question: Which preposition fits? 'He walked ___ the tunnel.'
exercises.example_sentence: He walked through the tunnel to get to the other side of the hill.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.example_sentence: The weather is bad, so you should drive more carefully.

exercises.question: Match the modal verb to its meaning.
exercises.hint: Think about the function of the word.
exercises.example_sentence: I can swim, and you should learn too.

exercises.question: Repeat: It’s the best movie I’ve ever seen.
exercises.answer: It’s the best movie I’ve ever seen.
exercises.example_sentence: You must watch it; it’s the best movie I’ve ever seen.

exercises.question: I decided ___ a new car.
exercises.hint: The verb 'decide' is followed by the infinitive.
exercises.example_sentence: I decided to buy a new car because my old one kept breaking down.

exercises.question: Identify the correct preposition: 'She climbed ___ the stairs.'
exercises.example_sentence: She climbed up the stairs to her bedroom.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: This one is better than that
exercises.example_sentence: I prefer this phone; this one is better than that one.

exercises.question: Match the opposite prepositions.
exercises.example_sentence: He walked into the shop and then walked out of it.

exercises.question: Repeat: She is as smart as her sister.
exercises.answer: She is as smart as her sister.
exercises.example_sentence: Both girls are top of their class; she is as smart as her sister.

exercises.question: They ___ go to France this summer, but they aren't sure.
exercises.example_sentence: They may go to France this summer if they save enough money.

exercises.question: Which is correct? 'I don't mind ___.'
exercises.hint: 'Don't mind' is followed by a gerund.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm not in a hurry, so I don't mind waiting for you.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: He got out of the car
exercises.hint: Preposition of movement from inside to outside.
exercises.example_sentence: He arrived at the hotel and got out of the car.

exercises.question: Match the phrase to the meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll call you as soon as I arrive.

exercises.question: Repeat: We might not have enough time.
exercises.answer: We might not have enough time.
exercises.example_sentence: The train leaves soon; we might not have enough time for coffee.

exercises.question: You haven't seen my keys, ___ you?
exercises.hint: Question tags: use a positive tag for a negative sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: You haven't seen my keys anywhere, have you?

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct?
options: I have seen that movie yesterday.
I have see that movie yesterday.
exercises.hint: Use Past Simple when you mention a specific time (yesterday).
exercises.example_sentence: I saw that movie yesterday, and I really enjoyed it.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Do you have to wear a uniform ?
exercises.hint: Question about obligation at work or school.
exercises.example_sentence: Do you have to wear a uniform for your new job?

exercises.question: Match the relative pronoun to its use.
exercises.hint: Think about the object or person the pronoun describes.
exercises.example_sentence: That is the house where I was born.

exercises.question: Repeat: It’s a lovely day, isn’t it?
exercises.answer: It’s a lovely day, isn’t it?
exercises.hint: Falling intonation for a statement you expect someone to agree with.
exercises.example_sentence: The sun is shining. It’s a lovely day, isn’t it?

exercises.question: She ___ lived in Paris for three years.
exercises.hint: Present Perfect: Subject + has/have + past participle.
exercises.example_sentence: She has lived in Paris for three years and speaks French fluively.

exercises.question: What is the meaning of 'You don't have to go'?
options: It is not necessary for you to go.
You are not allowed to go.
exercises.answer: It is not necessary for you to go.
exercises.hint: 'Don't have to' means lack of obligation.
exercises.example_sentence: It's a holiday, so you don't have to go to work today.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The man whose car this is is my brother
exercises.hint: This is a complex sentence using a possessive relative clause.
exercises.example_sentence: The man whose car this is is my brother.

exercises.question: Match the tense to the keyword.
exercises.hint: Keywords help you decide which tense to use.
exercises.example_sentence: I have been here since 9 AM.

exercises.question: Repeat: He doesn’t like tea, does he?
exercises.answer: He doesn’t like tea, does he?
exercises.example_sentence: He only drinks coffee. He doesn’t like tea, does he?

exercises.question: This is the town ___ I grew up.
exercises.example_sentence: This is the town where I grew up before moving to the city.

exercises.question: Which is correct? 'I have ___ to Italy.'
exercises.hint: Use 'been' for a completed visit (you went and came back).
exercises.example_sentence: I have been to Italy twice, and I love the food there.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: You must not forget to call her
exercises.example_sentence: It is her birthday, so you must not forget to call her.

exercises.question: Match the opposites.
exercises.hint: The negative forms have very different meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: You must go, but you don't have to stay.

exercises.question: Repeat: I’ve already finished my lunch.
exercises.hint: The keyword 'already' goes between the auxiliary and the participle.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm not hungry. I’ve already finished my lunch.

exercises.question: We ___ any milk left in the fridge.
exercises.example_sentence: We haven't got any milk left, so I need to go to the store.

exercises.question: Report: 'I am coming tomorrow.'
options: He said he was coming the next day.
He said he is coming tomorrow.
exercises.answer: He said he was coming the next day.
exercises.hint: Both the tense and the time expression change in reported speech.
exercises.example_sentence: I spoke to him and he said he was coming the next day.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The Nile is the longest river in the world
exercises.example_sentence: The Nile is the longest river in the world, flowing through many countries.

exercises.question: Match the tag to the sentence.
exercises.hint: The tag uses the same auxiliary verb as the sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: She is nice, isn't she?

exercises.question: Repeat: I haven’t seen him for ages.
exercises.answer: I haven’t seen him for ages.
exercises.hint: Using 'for' with a period of time.
exercises.example_sentence: I wonder how John is doing; I haven’t seen him for ages.

exercises.question: I ___ to that restaurant three times this month.
exercises.hint: Use Present Perfect for an unfinished time period (this month).
exercises.example_sentence: I have been to that restaurant three times this month because the food is great.

exercises.question: Which sentence is a correct negative in the Present Perfect?
options: I haven't finished my work yet.
I didn't finished my work yet.
I haven't finish my work yet.
exercises.answer: I haven't finished my work yet.
exercises.example_sentence: I haven't finished my work yet, so I need another hour.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Have you ever seen a whale ?
exercises.example_sentence: Have you ever seen a whale while on vacation?

exercises.question: Match the word to its grammar category.
exercises.hint: Adjectives describe nouns; adverbs describe verbs.
exercises.example_sentence: She is a beautiful singer and she sings quickly.

exercises.question: Repeat: I went to Italy last summer.
exercises.answer: I went to Italy last summer.
exercises.hint: Use Past Simple for a finished time (last summer).
exercises.example_sentence: I went to Italy last summer and visited Rome.

exercises.question: You ___ park here. It's for doctors only.
exercises.example_sentence: You can't park here because this space is reserved.

exercises.question: Choose the correct preposition: 'The plane flew ___ the mountains.'
exercises.example_sentence: The plane flew over the mountains during the sunset.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: You should listen carefully to the instructions
exercises.example_sentence: You should listen carefully to the instructions before starting.

exercises.question: Match the infinitive to the past participle.
exercises.example_sentence: I have eaten breakfast already.

exercises.question: Repeat: She has already left the office.
exercises.answer: She has already left the office.
exercises.example_sentence: You missed her; she has already left the office.

exercises.question: We ___ any problems so far.
exercises.example_sentence: The project is going well; we haven't had any problems so far.

exercises.question: What is the opposite of 'always'?
exercises.example_sentence: He never eats meat because he is a vegetarian.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: The city is more expensive than the countryside
exercises.example_sentence: Living in the city is more expensive than the countryside.

exercises.question: Match the auxiliary to the tense.
exercises.hint: Used for forming questions and negatives.
exercises.example_sentence: Do you like coffee? Did you like the movie?

exercises.question: Repeat: I’ve known him for ten years.
exercises.answer: I’ve known him for ten years.
exercises.example_sentence: He is my best friend; I’ve known him for ten years.

exercises.question: They were walking ___ the beach when it started to rain.
exercises.hint: Movement following a line (like a shore or road).
exercises.example_sentence: They were walking along the beach when it started to rain.

exercises.question: Choose the correct comparative: 'This task is ___ than the last one.'
exercises.hint: Two-syllable adjectives ending in -y change to -ier.
exercises.example_sentence: I finished quickly because this task is easier than the last one.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: If you help me I will be happy
exercises.example_sentence: If you help me with this, I will be very happy.

exercises.question: Match the start to the end of the phrasal verb.
exercises.example_sentence: I wake up at 7 AM.

exercises.question: Repeat: Whose phone is this?
exercises.example_sentence: I found this on the table. Whose phone is this?

exercises.question: I don't have ___ luggage to carry.
exercises.hint: Luggage is an uncountable noun in English.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't have much luggage, so I can take the bus.

exercises.question: Which preposition is correct for a specific time? 'I'll see you ___ 8:30.'
exercises.example_sentence: I'll see you at 8:30 in front of the cinema.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: She drinks coffee in the morning
exercises.hint: Use 'in the' for parts of the day.
exercises.example_sentence: She always drinks coffee in the morning to wake up.

exercises.question: Match the modal to its level of certainty.
exercises.hint: One is for facts/promises, the other for guesses.
exercises.example_sentence: It will be cold tomorrow; it might snow.

exercises.question: Repeat: Do you have any sugar?
exercises.hint: Sugar is uncountable; use 'any' in questions.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm making a cake. Do you have any sugar?

exercises.question: We visited Paris ___ 2022.
exercises.example_sentence: We visited Paris in 2022 and loved the museums.

exercises.question: Complete the phrase: 'I'm interested ___ learning photography.'
exercises.hint: The adjective 'interested' always takes this preposition.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm interested in learning photography this summer.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: My brother is older than me
exercises.example_sentence: My brother is older than me by three years.

exercises.question: Match the verb to the activity.
exercises.example_sentence: I want to go shopping and play tennis later.

exercises.question: Repeat: My birthday is on June 5th.
exercises.example_sentence: Don't forget my birthday is on June 5th!

exercises.question: They ___ to the gym every morning.
exercises.hint: Present simple for a daily habit.
exercises.example_sentence: They go to the gym every morning before work.

exercises.question: Which is the correct past participle of 'fly'?
exercises.example_sentence: I have never flown in a helicopter before.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: There is no money in the wallet
exercises.example_sentence: I can't buy coffee because there is no money in the wallet.

exercises.question: Match the singular to the irregular plural.
exercises.example_sentence: There are many children and people in the park.

exercises.question: Repeat: I was reading when she arrived.
exercises.answer: I was reading when she arrived.
exercises.hint: Review: Past Continuous and Past Simple combination.
exercises.example_sentence: I was reading a book when she arrived home.

exercises.question: I would like ___ orange juice, please.
exercises.example_sentence: I would like some orange juice with my breakfast, please.

exercises.question: Complete: 'We have lived here ___ 2010.'
exercises.hint: Use 'since' for a starting point in time.
exercises.example_sentence: We have lived here since 2010 and know all our neighbors.

exercises.question: Order the words:
exercises.answer: Who is the man wearing the blue hat ?
exercises.hint: Question using a present participle to describe someone.
exercises.example_sentence: Who is the man wearing the blue hat near the gate?

exercises.question: Match the question word to its purpose.
exercises.example_sentence: How often do you swim? How long is the movie?

exercises.question: Repeat: She doesn’t have many friends.
exercises.hint: Use 'many' for countable nouns in negative sentences.
exercises.example_sentence: She is shy, so she doesn’t have many friends yet.
